definition: An A/B test aims to compare the performance of two items or variations against one another. In product management, A/B tests are often used to identify the best-performing option.
What is an acceptance test? Learn more about acceptance testing and other agile practices and terminology in our agile glossary.

An affinity diagram helps teams visualize and review large amounts of information by grouping items into categories. This post discusses why affinity diagrams are useful and will walk you through how to build your own.
An agile framework is one of many documented software-development approaches based on the agile philosophy articulated in the Agile Manifesto.
What is an Agile Product Owner? In an agile organization, the product owner is responsible for prioritizing and overseeing...

Agile Values refers to the set of 4 values outlined by the Agile Alliance in The Agile Manifesto. This set of values encourages putting people before processes, getting software out the door fast, collaborating with customers, and adjusting plans as needed.
A single, guiding metric that reflects long-term business success.
A framework to set measurable goals that connect strategy with execution.
Quantifiable metrics to track progress on specific outcomes.
A future-facing statement of what the product aims to achieve long-term.
Defines the product’s purpose and approach to achieving the vision.
Core themes or focus areas that guide product strategy.
The point when a product satisfies strong market demand.
A fictional representation of your target user segment.
A user’s specific frustration or problem your product aims to solve.
A framework focusing on what users “hire” a product to do.
A visual flow of how users interact with your product.
Observing real users as they use your product to validate design decisions.
Dividing users into groups based on needs or behavior.
A tool to visualize what users think, feel, say, and do.
The smallest product version that delivers value and validates assumptions.
A prioritized list of tasks or features to be developed.
Methods to decide which features to build first (e.g., RICE, MoSCoW).
Formula: (Reach × Impact × Confidence) / Effort — helps rank initiatives.
Categorizes tasks as Must-have, Should-have, Could-have, Won’t-have.
Classifies features as basic, performance, or delight factors.
A compromise between features, time, and resources.
Low-fidelity visual layout of a product screen.
A high-fidelity design showing what the final interface looks like.
Interactive simulation of the product before coding.
User Interface / User Experience — design disciplines focusing on usability and aesthetics.
The cost of choosing an easy solution now instead of a better one later.
Application Programming Interface — rules that allow software systems to communicate.
A fixed time-boxed period (usually 1–2 weeks) to deliver specific work.
Agile methodologies for organizing team workflows.
Strategy for launching and promoting a product to users.
A limited release to a small user group for feedback.
How quickly users start using a new feature/product.
The point when a user experiences value for the first time.
The percentage of users who continue using your product over time.
The rate at which users stop using your product.
Tracking user behavior over time by segment.
The stepwise flow users go through from awareness to conversion.
Daily Active Users / Monthly Active Users.
Cost of acquiring a new user.
Total revenue expected from a customer over their lifespan.
Percentage of users completing a desired action.
User loyalty metric based on survey responses.
How frequently or deeply users interact with your product.
% of new users who reach their first “aha” moment.
Anyone with interest or influence in the product.
Teams that include PMs, designers, engineers, and marketers.
Ensuring everyone understands and supports the same priorities.
Tasks or teams that rely on each other for delivery.
Raising a blocker or decision to leadership.
The initial idea or proposal for a product or feature.
Phase where a product gains traction and grows its user base.
When product growth stabilizes and focus shifts to efficiency and optimization.
When a product or feature is retired or its usage steadily decreases over time.
A cycle of updates and improvements based on feedback and metrics.
The cadence and process for shipping releases to users.
Ongoing work required to keep the product stable, secure, and up-to-date.
